questions.question: Which of the following are not true regarding external hemorrhoids?
questions.explanation: External hemorrhoids are painful, self-curing and covered by squamous epithelium. The branchesof the superior rectal vein, located at 3, 7, and 11 o'clock positions in the anal canal are commonsites for internal hemorrhoids. Banding is preferred for internal hemorrhoids.Hemorrhoids are cushions of submucosal tissue containing venules, arterioles, smooth musclefibres, and elastic connective tissue. They can be classified according to their location into 2 types:• Internal Hemorrhoids•External HemorrhoidsNote: Repeated thrombosis leads to a semi-ripe black currant appearance of externalhemorrhoids.Internal analsphincterExternal analsphincterInternalhemorrhoidProlapsing InternalhemorrhoidExternal hemorrhoidTypes of HemorrhoidsPectinatelinePerianalvesselsOMARROW623

questions.question: A man presented with bleeding per rectum which he noticed after passing stools for the past 2weeks. On straining, a reddish mass as shown in the image was seen protruding out of theanal canal. It did not reduce spontaneously and had to be manually reduced. What is thegrade of hemorrhoids in this patient?
questions.explanation: In the given scenario, as the prolapsed haemorrhoids required manual reduction, it is suggestiveof third-degree haemorrhoids.

questions.question: In patients with which of the following conditions can injection sclerotherapy be ideally used?
questions.explanation: Injection sclerotherapy is ideal for the treatment of first and second-degree hemorrhoids (bleedingor spontaneously reducing hemorrhoids).1 to 3 mL of a sclerosing solution (phenol in olive oil, sodium morrhuate, or quinine urea) isinjected into the submucosa of each hemorrhoid. Complications of sclerotherapy include infectionand fibrosis.

questions.question: A 48-year-old man presents to the clinic with severe anorectal pain during and afterdefecation. The pain was present for 6 months but has increased in severity over the past 1day. Examination finding is shown below. A per-rectal examination could not be performeddue to pain. How will you manage this patient?
questions.explanation: 624The clinical features and the image are suggestive of thrombosed external hemorrhoids. Patientswho present within 48 hours of thrombosis should undergo thrombus evacuation under localanesthesia. This procedure involves the removal of the clot with an elliptical incision on the skin.After the initial 48-72 hours, pain typically plateaus and hence the patient is treatedconservatively with analgesics and a sitz bath.Grade1, grade 2, and some grade 3 hemorrhoids with only an internal component can be treatedwith simple procedures like rubber band ligation, sclerotherapy, infrared and laser coagulation,and cryotherapy.Surgery is indicated in:• Internal grade 3 or grade 4 hemorrhoids• Hemorrhoids with a significant external component.•Early grade hemorrhoids not responding to simple proceduresSurgical procedures used in the removal of hemorrhoids are:Open (Milligan-Morgan) hemorrhoidectomy• Closed (Ferguson) hemorrhoidectomy•Stapled hemorrhoidopexy - is circumferential rectal mucosectomy. It is associated with reducedpostoperative pain, faster recovery and shorter hospital stay•Doppler-guided hemorrhoidal artery ligationOpen hemorrhoidectomy - Artery forceps are applied to the skin-covered external components ofthe hemorrhoid and traction is given to reveal the internal components. Dissection of the lateralpedicle is performed and finally, the pedicles are transfixed. Mucocutaneous bridges are left intactin this technique. The image below shows the procedure.Open hemorroidectomyPlacement of 3 clamps on the hemorrhoidal groupDissection ofhemorrhoidal groupsSuture ligature withoutclosure of woundFinal post operative appearanceOMARROWClosed hemorrhoidectomy - The hemorrhoid is excised with the overlying mucosa. Thehemorrhoid is dissected from the underlying sphincter and the mucus defect is then closed. Thistechnique is associated with higher chances of recurrence. This procedure is however quick toperform and less painful. The image below describes the procedure.625Closed HaemorrhoidectomyThe haemorrhoidal tissue is excisedNBleeding is controlled by diathermyMWThe defect is closed with a continuous suture after firstundermining the anoderm on each sideMARROW

questions.question: What is the most common complication following hemorrhoidectomy?
questions.explanation: Urinary retention is the most common complication following hemorrhoidectomy.Conventional hemorrhoidectomy(open or closed technique), is considered to be an extremelypainful procedure. Dysfunction of the detrusor muscle or the trigone in response to pain ordistention of the anal canal or perineum has been postulated as the cause of urinary retentionpost hemorrhoidectomy.Other complications include:• Fecal incontinence• Infection• Delayed hemorrhage• Stricture

questions.question: A 35-year-old man came with complaints of chronic constipation, blood-streaked stools, andpain during defecation for 2 months. On examination, a sentinel tag was noted at the analorifice. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: In the given scenario, the presence of a sentinel tag is suggestive of chronic anal fissure.An anal fissure is a linear or oval-shaped tear in the anal canal starting just below the dentate lineextending to the anal verge. It can be acute or chronic.Chronic anal fissures last for more than 6-8 weeks, and are frequently associated with a triad offindings:• Sentinel tag• Hypertrophied anal papillae at the upper end of the fissure in the anal canal• Deep canoe-shaped ulcer626Acute fissures are shallow tears in the anoderm. They are associated with:• Anal pain•Spasm•Bleeding with defecationThe below image shows features of a chronic anal fissureChronic Anal FissureOMARROWHypertrophicpapillaAnal sphincterAnal fissure(ulcer)Sentinel pile

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common location of anal fissures?
questions.explanation: Over 90% of fissures are located in the posterior midline, with the rest being located in theanterior midline of the anal canal.The main hypothesis is that the posterior midline area may have decreased blood flow due to theconfiguration of the blood vessels of the anus. Also, the spasm of the internal anal sphincter maycause further reduction of the blood flow to the posterior anal canal.

questions.question: What is the procedure of choice in a patient with chronic anal fissure?
questions.explanation: Lateral internal sphincterotomy is the procedure of choice for chronic anal fissures.Surgical therapy has traditionally been recommended for chronic anal fissures that have failedmedical therapy. The aim of this procedure is to decrease the spasms of the internal sphincter bydividing a portion of the muscle. Approximately 30% of the muscle sphincter fibers are dividedlaterally using an open or closed technique.The initial treatment of anal fissures includes:⚫ Frequent sitz baths• Analgesics627• Stool softeners• High-fiber dietIf conservative management with dietary changes and laxatives fail, other options includingtopical analgesics such as 2% lidocaine jelly, topical nifedipine, topical nitroglycerin, or acombination of topical nifedipine and lidocaine can be attempted.Option A: Miligan-Morgan procedure is an open hemorrhoidectomyOption C: Transanal resection is used to remove early-stage rectal cancers in the lower rectumOption D: Altermeier's procedure is used for rectal prolapse

questions.question: Which type of anal fistula is seen in this image?617
questions.explanation: In the given image, the fistula traverses the internal sphincter and tracks down the space betweenthe internal and external anal sphincters. Hence, it is an inter-sphincteric type of anal fistula. It isthe most common anal fistula.A fistula-in-ano is an epithelial-lined tract connecting the anal canal to the perianal skin. Patientsusually complain of intermittent purulent discharge and pain. Anal fistulas can be simplex orcomplex fistulas.•Simple fistulas- include a single tract, subcutaneous tract, and those that involve less than 30%of the external sphincter. They are easier to treat, and have lower chances of recurrence.•Complex fistulas- include fistulas involving more than 30% of the external sphincter, withmultiple tracts, recurrent fistulas, and those associated with other predisposing factors, such asCrohn disease and radiation treatment.Fistulas can also be classified into high or low-lying fistulas, based on their location with respectto the puborectalis muscle.Inter-sphincteric type of anal fistulaInternal anal sphincterOMARROWExternal anal sphincter628

questions.question: A 40-year-old male patient presents to the clinic with a history of discharge from the perianalregion for the past 1 week. On examination, an external opening was seen at 2 o'clock positionaround the anal orifice. On per rectal examination, an opening was palpable at 3 o'clockposition at the dentate line. What is the gold standard investigation for assessing this patient?
questions.explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of an anal fistula. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the goldstandard investigation for fistula imaging. It helps to identify the secondary extensions of thetrack, which when missed may cause persistence of the fistula.Investigations available for fistula-in-ano are:.Fistulogram• Endoanal ultrasound• MRIComputed tomography (CT) scan• Endocoil MRI⚫ Hydrogen peroxide-enhanced 3-D endoanal ultrasonography•

questions.question: A patient presented with serous discharge from an opening located in the perianal region. Onexamination, the location of the external opening was at 8'0 clock position. According toGoodsall's rule at what position from the dentate line will the internal opening be palpated inthis patient?
questions.explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of fistula-in-ano with external opening at 8'0 clock positionwhich implies that the external opening of the fistula is lying posterior to the midline. Accordingto the Goodsall rule, fistulas with an external opening posteriorly track in a curvilinear fashion tothe posterior midline. Hence, the fistulous tract opens internally at a 6'0 clock position.A fistula-in-ano is an abnormal hollow tract or cavity that is lined with granulation tissue and thatconnects a primary opening inside the anal canal to a secondary opening in the perianal skin.Goodsall's rule:• Fistulas with an external opening anteriorly connect to the internal opening by a short, radialtract.• Fistulas with an external opening posteriorly track in a curvilinear fashion to the posteriormidline.However, exceptions to this rule often occur. Fistulas with an anterior external opening greaterthan 3 cm from the anal margin usually track to the posterior midline629Goodsall's ruleAnterior:straighttractsException:Long anteriorfistula(>3cm)3cm12 o'clockpositionPosterior:curved tracsOMARROWTransverse anal line

questions.question: A known case of Crohn's disease presented to the clinic with a history of discharge from theanal region for the past 2 weeks. The patient underwent drainage of an ischiorectal abscess 2months back. Clinical examination and imaging reveal the presence of a supra-sphinctericperianal fistula. How will you manage this patient?
questions.explanation: In the given scenario, a history of Crohn's disease, recurrent anorectal abscess, and the imagingfindings point towards a complex anal fistula. It will be managed using Seton's placement, whichis done in two stages.A seton is a drain placed through a fistula to maintain drainage and/or induce fibrosis. Setons canbe classified as draining or cutting.Seton's techniqueRectumFistulatractsSetonwPerianalabscessExternal drainageclose to anal sphincterOMARROWCutting setonA cutting seton has been used as a staged fistulectomy, especially in high trans-sphinctericfistulas. After the seton is passed during the primary surgery, it has to be tightened at regularintervals, till it cuts through completely.630Loose/draining setonIn this method, the seton is placed to maintain drainage and create scar tissue around thesphincter so that its edges do not retract after cutting.OMARROWOption B: Fistulotomy involves opening the fistula tract and possibly dividing the sphinctermuscle. It is very effective for simple fistulas with minimal sphincter involvement.Option C: Lateral internal sphincterotomy is a technique used for chronic anal fissures.Option D: In fistulectomy, the fistulous tract is cut out completely.•Other surgeries for fistula in-ano include:Endorectal advancement flap- involves closure of the internal opening of the tract, debridementof the tract, and mobilization of anorectal mucosa to cover the defect. It is usually done forcomplex fistulas.• LIFT- Ligation of the intersphincteric fistula tract involves identification of the internal openingwith suture ligation of the intersphincteric portion of the fistula. The tract and infected gland arethen excised and the wound is debrided with curettage. It can be done for both simple andcomplex fistulas.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common cause of anorectal suppuration?
questions.explanation: The most common cause of anorectal suppuration is nonspecific cryptoglandular infection.Anorectal abscess originates from an infection arising in the cryptoglandular epithelium lining theanal canal. The increased incidence of ischio-rectal fossa infection is due to poor blood supply.It may also be caused by other reasons such as:• Crohn's disease• Trauma631• Immunodeficiency resulting from human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection or malignancy(both hematologic and anorectal cancer)•• Tuberculosis• Hidradenitis suppurativa

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common type of anorectal abscess?
questions.explanation: A perianal abscess is the most common type of anorectal abscess.Anorectal abscess refers to a collection of pus in the anal or rectal region. More commonly seen inmen. There are four types of anorectal abscesses:• Peri-anal (most common)• Ischio-rectal• Inter-sphincteric• Supra-levatorTreatment: Drainage of pus + AntibioticsSupralevatorIschiorectalInternalanal sphincterIntersphinctericPerianalTypes of anorectal abscessAnusOMARROWRectumExternalanalsphincter

questions.question: 619A jeep driver presented with a swelling in the natal cleft, with pain, difficulty in sitting, andoccasional purulent discharge from the area. Examination finding is shown below. Which ofthe following is not true regarding this condition?

options.B: Hair follicles are seen in the wall of sinus
options.C: Hirsute habitus is a risk factor
options.D: Commonly seen between the ages of 15 and 40 years

questions.explanation: The given condition is a pilonidal sinus. Hair follicles have almost never been demonstrated in thewalls of the sinus. The hair projecting from the sinus is dead hair, with its pointed ends directedtowards the blind end of the sinus.Pilonidal sinus disease is a disease of the inter-gluteal region, characterized by the formation of asinus in the cleft of the buttocks. It is more common in males between 15-40 years of age.Risk factors include:632•Male sex•Family history•Being overweight or obese••• Trauma or irritation to the perianal regionOccupations involving sitting for long periods- jeep/lorry drivers• Hirsute habitus - thick body hair• Poor hygieneSites involved:• Natal cleft (most commonly)• Interdigital cleft• Face• AxillaButtock friction and shearing forces in these areas allow broken hairs to enter the skin and createa subcutaneous, chronically infected midline track. An infected hair follicle can also form such atrack. Secondary tracks can arise as openings, lined with granulation tissue and discharge.Clinical features:• Intermittent pain, swelling, and discharge at the base of the spine.• Abscess - due to a foreign-body-type reactionTreatment• Conservative treatment: Strict hygiene and regular shaving of hair in the area.• Abscess:•Rest, baths, local antiseptic dressings, and broad-spectrum antibiotics..• If refractory to the above treatment- drainage with thorough curettage of granulation tissue andhair..Surgical techniques: Bascom's, Karydaki's procedures are for chronic pilonidal disease.Recurrence is common even after adequate excision of the tract.

questions.question: Which of the following is not used in the treatment of pilonidal sinus diseases?
questions.explanation: Surgical approaches parallel to the natal cleft, and not along the natal cleft are preferred, toreduce chances of recurrence.Pilonidal sinus disease treatment includes non-surgical and surgical approaches. The non-surgicalapproach includes conservative treatment with proper hygiene and regular shaving of hair in thearea.In case of an abscess- adequate rest, baths, local antiseptic dressings, and broad-spectrumantibiotics are advised.633Surgical approaches for the management of pilonidal sinus disease include:• Incision and drainage- for pilonidal abscess refractory to medical treatment• Bascom's procedure- is a cleft lift procedure in which hair follicles parallel to the natal cleft areremoved under local anesthesia• Karydakis procedure- an ovoid area of pathologic tissue is excised parallel to the natal cleft and afasciocutaneous flap is mobilized to cover the defect• Limberg/ rhomboid flap- excises the pilonidal disease in a rhomboid shape and rotates afasciocutaneous flap for wound closure.• Others- VY advancement flaps, and Z-plastyThe given image shows a Limberg/rhomboid flap done in pilonidal sinus surgery:

questions.question: An elderly female presented with severe persisting per rectal itching for the past 1 year,despite standard topical therapy. On examination, irregular eczematous lesions were seen atthe anal orifice. Biopsy of the lesion revealed large vacuolated cells containing mucin. Whichof the following is it likely to be?620
questions.explanation: The given history and presence of large vacuolated cells (Paget cells) on biopsy is suggestive ofPaget's disease of the anal canal. It is a rare intraepithelial adenocarcinoma.Paget's disease is most commonly seen in areas with a high density of apocrine sweat glands, inelderly females. These can develop into an invasive cancer of the underlying apocrine glands.Clinical features include intractable itching, burning, bleeding per rectally. 10% of the patients areasymptomatic. On examination, eczematous, well-demarcated plaque, with occasional ulcerationand scaling can be seen.On histology presence of Paget cells (large, vacuolated cells with mucin) confirms the diagnosis.Treatment:• Treatment of choice- complete excision•Limited, noninvasive disease-wide local excision and closure of the defect with primary suturesor with V-Y advancement flaps634• Invasive component- radical resection with abdominoperineal resection (APR)• Medically unfit for surgery - topical 5-FU, imiquimod, cryotherapy, or argon beam laser therapy• Recurrence- re-excision (as long as the disease remains noninvasive)Note: Most common site of extra-mammary Paget's disease - anogenital region > axilla >eyelid. Perianal Paget's disease is usually associated with underlying visceral malignancy, mostcommonly colorectal adenocarcinoma.

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal?

options.A: Proctoscopy is the investigation of choice
options.C: Most common presentation is ano-rectal pain
options.D: Most common type of anal canal carcinoma

questions.explanation: Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is the most common anal canal carcinoma. SCC > Basal cellcarcinoma >MelanomaThe median age at diagnosis for SCC is 60 years. Patients most commonly present with bleedingper rectum. Commonly metastasizes to the liver and lungs. The most common site of lymph nodemetastasis is to inguinal lymph nodes.Risk Factors:• Human papillomavirus (HPV) (types 16, 18, 31, 33) infection• Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) or immunosuppression•Smoking• Anal receptive intercourse•Sexual promiscuity• Anal intraepithelial neoplasia•History of vulvar or cervical cancerDiagnosis:•• Proctoscopy with biopsy- investigation of choice•• MRI- for local staging• CT scan to evaluate for distant metastasis.Treatment :Nigro regimen- chemoradiation is the treatment of choice• If any residual tumor is left behind after chemoradiation, abdominoperineal resection (APR) isperformed8th AJCC: TNM Classification of Carcinoma of the Anal Canal and Anal MarginPrimary Tumor:6358th AJCC: TNM Classification of Carcinoma of the Anal Canal and Anal Margin-Tis - high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesionT1 - 2 cm.or lessT2 - >2 - 5 cmT3 - >5 cmT4 invades adjacent organ,e.g. vagina, urethra, bladder.(invasion of the rectal wall, perirectal skin, subcutaneous tissue, or sphincter muscle isnot included as T4).Regional Nodes:Regional lymph nodes include mesorectal, inguinal (superficial, deep), superior rectal (hemorrhoidal), external iliac, and internal iliac (hypogastric)groups. No no regional lymph node metastasesNia - inguinal, mesorectal, or internaliliac lymph nodesNib - external iliac nodesNic external iliac nodes + Nia--Distant Metastases:Mo noM1 - yes-Stage grouping:o TisI - T1 NOIIA - T2 NOIIB T3 NOIIIA - T1-2 N1IIIB---T4 NOIIIC T3-4 N1IV - M1

questions.question: A 60-year-old man with bleeding per rectum is suspected to have squamous cell carcinoma ofthe anal canal. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?

options.D: Surgical excision with CO2 laser treatment

questions.explanation: Treatment of choice for squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal is Nigro regimen/chemoradiation.A combination of 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) with mitomycin C/ cisplatin is followed by external beamradiation to the pelvis with a minimum dose of 45 Gy.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about melanoma of the anal canal?

options.A: Wide local excision is done for tumors with sphincter involvement
options.B: Staged by depth or thickness of melanoma lesion

questions.explanation: Anorectal melanoma is staged by the depth or thickness of the lesion.Anal canal melanoma is more common in females. The tumor appears as small and polypoidal orlarge and ulcerating. Clinical features include:• Anorectal bleeding, itching, pain, mass636•Tenesmus, and changes in bowel habits• Mesorectal lymph node metastases.• Inguinal lymphadenopathy•Distant spread- to bones, lungs, and liverDiagnosis is frequently made following hemorrhoidectomy or local excision of the perianal mass.Treatment:•⚫ Tumors without anal sphincter involvement- wide local excision with negative margins.• Large tumors invading sphincters- palliative APRRegardless of stage, 5-year survival rates for anorectal melanoma are very poor, averaging atabout 6%. The median survival time following diagnosis is 12–18 months.Note: Most common sites of melanoma are skin >eye > anorectal region637
